title: Is the Love Song Dying?
description: We categorized songs in the Billboard Top 10 to see if love songs are on the decline.
byline: By David Mora and Michelle Jia

bios.david: makes visual explorations of cultural phenomena, like meat, Olivia Rodrigo, and MrBeast. Usually with Michelle Jia. And sometimes even Michelle Pera-McGhee.
bios.michelle: is a writer and ethnographic researcher from Toronto. She made an indie folk album. She picked apart Ariana Grande. Twice. She makes things with David, who wrote this bio.

dataMethods.title: How did you determine the popularity of each song?
paragraphs: TLDR: popularity = number of weeks in the Billboard Top 10 (does not have to be continuous weeks)

Coming up with a popularity metric was tricky. First, Billboard continuously changed how they chose the rank of the Hot 100. In the ‚Äô60s, they loosely polled record stores, and sometimes just switched things up to keep it interesting. Later they started looking at stream count, which measures completely different user behavior (e.g., it takes into account those who listen to songs on repeat, which radio never could).

For example: You might notice that, as time goes on, there seem to be fewer songs, and songs on average spend longer in the Top 10. Are today‚Äôs songs just‚Ä¶ more popular than ever? Unclear. It‚Äôs hard to know how much of this comes from changing listener behavior vs how Billboard measures listener behavior.

The best we can do is compare the relative popularity of a song to songs from the same era. It‚Äôs not safe to conclude, say, that Doja Cat‚Äôs Kiss Me More was more popular than The Beatle‚Äôs Day Tripper simply because it spent longer on the Top 10. Popularity was measured completely differently for each.

Second, even if Billboard rankings were made consistently, rankings (‚Äúordinal measures,‚Äù for the geeks) kinda suck for deriving aggregate, quantitative comparisons. Billboard provides us each song‚Äôs rank, but nothing about how close or far one song was from another. For example, in January 2019, was Hasley‚Äôs Without Me at #1 because it was twice as popular as Ariana‚Äôs Thank U, Next #2? Or did it barely edge it out?

The data is messy, so we ended up keeping our popularity metric simple: tally the total number of weeks the song was within the Top 10, irrespective of its specific rank. The popularity scores derived from this approach closely correlate with scoring methods that take rank into account, so we felt pretty happy proceeding with it.

dataMethods.title: How did you decide which of the 5,100 songs were love songs?
paragraphs: We did a lot of labeling by hand. Once we had a solid approach (see below) and a lot of examples, we wrote a prompt and used GPT4o to label the rest. We iterated a lot on that prompt until it became pretty accurate. By the end, we found GPT made very few mistakes, and most mistakes we did find were simply songs that would have been genuinely ambiguous for a human labeler, as well.

I, David, was honestly very surprised by how accurate GPT4o ended up being, after a lot of experimentation. Eventually, we found that model accuracy was most improved by: (a) in the output, having the model first write a justification before making its final categorization and (b) in the prompt, providing a lot of examples with justifications.

The explanation for this seems related to how LLMs work: since they generate outputs token by token, giving the model space to first ‚Äúthink through‚Äù a justification results in a more accurate classification. And, naturally, more examples increased the model‚Äôs clarity on our classification system.

dataMethods.title: [SPOILER ALERT] How did you develop and and then assign your seven love song types?
paragraphs: I, Michelle, come from a qualitative research background, so we used a process called "clustering" to find "themes" in a large volume of qualitative data (in this case, music and lyrics). (Mentally, this is a similar process to what happens when Humanities scholars find the themes in a body of literary or philosophical work!)

We started with the most obvious song types -- the Serenade -- and slowly expanded towards types that seemed to defy these, until we had created a collection of themes that seemed to represent the vast majority, if not all of the songs. This process involved going back and forth between our own lived experience of what love songs existed, and testing the framework -- with GPT4o's help -- against the actual data to find exceptions and improve our model. Every time GPT4o came back with labelled data, we combed through by hand to see how much we agreed. The disagreements produced new insights.
Still not satisfied? Ok, here‚Äôs a bit more of the details:
At our least structured, we were simply assessing the songs we saw, and adjusting categories to better match them.
At our most structured (and where we tried to start the process), we came up with a matrix made of two metrics. Here it is:
love-song-type-matrix-attempt.png

Here‚Äôs how it worked: Given love songs are fundamentally about the romantic dynamics between (at least) two people, the first metric defined the relationship between the speaker and their subject: the speaker has/had feelings toward someone, and they either (a) might love them back, (b) do love them back or (c) don‚Äôt love them back (but might have once). The second metric was how traditional the treatment of love was. As you can see, the less traditional love song types often straddle multiple relationship categories.
In the end, we felt the framework was more confusing than helpful, but it helped us land on our ultimate love song categories.

Ultimately, there is no perfect set of categories that could capture the nuance of every love song, and we had to make a lot of interpretive leaps. Many songs straddle the line between two categories, and in those cases, we had to make judgement calls.
For the data nerds:
We did also try looking for clusters in a text embedding of each song‚Äôs lyrics. This yielded poor initial results, so we didn‚Äôt explore it futher.
Text embedding tended to cluster songs around the literal words and images they used, rather than the meaning or intent behind the words.

For example, while our ChatGPT prompt was able to correctly place Urgent by Foreigner into the category Sexual Confidence, text embedding failed to cluster it with other such songs because it consists largely of innuendo (eg ‚ÄúThat's why you call me in the middle of the night / You say it's urgent‚Äù).

The prevalence of songs like Urgent -- which are thematically related but textually quite different from other songs like WAP -- made LLMs a better choice than text embedding. Or maybe I, David, just need to get better at embedding and clustering ü§∑.

dataMethods.title: Besides what you did by hand and with an LLM, where did you get your data?
paragraphs: From this scrape of weekly Billboard Hot 100 rankings we looked at songs from 1959 - September 2023 (the cutoff date was chosen to be safety within the window that OpenAI‚Äôs GPT4o was trained on). There are 5,141 unique songs.
We used GPT to split out individual artist artists from the credit of each song. We merged some names where there was variation in the same artist‚Äôs name or spelling (eg Jay-Z and JAY-Z).

commentText.boomerBobComment: They don't make love songs like they used to‚Ä¶ Nowadays it's just sex, drugs and me me me!!!
commentText.alternate: They don‚Äôt make love songs like they used to‚Ä¶ No cussing, no nudity, just pure talent!

haveYouSeenTheseYouTubeComments.copy: Have you ever seen a comment like this? Boomer Bob is pointing to a growing sentiment: that something about contemporary music is in decline.

boomerBobSaysLoveSongsAreDying.copy: This Baby Boomer-centric sentiment seems to crystallize around one topic in particular: modern pop music‚Äôs treatment of love and romance‚Äîor the lack thereof. According to Boomer Bob, the love song is dying. But is it true? Let‚Äôs investigate...

allTheBillboardHitsInAMonoChromeCluster.copy: Here are all 5,100 Billboard Top 10 hits from 1958 to September 2023. Each bubble is a song. The bigger the bubble, the longer it spent in the Top 10.
allTheBillboardHitsInAMonoChromeCluster.figCaption: All five thousand one hundred Billboard Top 10 hits from 1958 to September 2023 represented as randomly distributed bubbles, each sized by how long it spent in the Top 10. Four songs are labeled.

highlightSerenadesWithinCluster.copy: These are the 1,040 Top 10 hits we think Boomer Bob would definitely consider love songs. They‚Äôre all unmistakably about romantic love and devotion, sung from one person to another. Let‚Äôs call these Serenades.
highlightSerenadesWithinCluster.figCaption: Highlighting the one thousand and forty classic love songs, also called ‚ÄúSerenades,‚Äù within the five thousand Billboard Top 10 hits, all represented as randomly distributed bubbles, with four playable love songs annotated.

serenadesAreIndeedDying.copy: If you spread these Serenades on a timeline, they do appear to decline‚Ä¶ but by how much?
serenadesAreIndeedDying.figCaption: All one thousand Serenade category love songs spread across a horizontal timeline from 1958 to 2023, appearing to peak in total popularity in the 1990s before substantially decreasing. Three songs are labeled.

anAggSnakeChartMakesBoomerBobSeemRight.copy: To see, here are the Serenades compared to all other Billboard Top 10 hits. The proportion of love songs in the 1960s was 23%. In the 2020s, it‚Äôs 12%. The proportion of love songs has almost halved! So, was Boomer Bob right? Are love songs, in fact, dying?
anAggSnakeChartMakesBoomerBobSeemRight.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of songs that are Serenades vs all other songs, where Serenades decrease from SIXTIES_PERCENT% in the 60s to MODERN_PERCENT% in the 2020s, dropping most sharply after the 1990s.

butWeWillTakeAMoreExpansiveView.copy: Not quite: we think Boomer Bob has too narrow a view of love. Sure, these lovey-dovey tunes have declined. But what about other songs? What about Adele‚Äôs Someone Like You? Or T-Pain‚Äôs Buy U A Drank? Or WAP? If we look more closely, we uncover a story that will change how you see love in pop music.
butWeWillTakeAMoreExpansiveView.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of songs that are Serenades vs all other songs, where each song is an individual bubble, with three playable songs annotated that relate to love but do not fit into the Serenade category.

definingSerenades.copy: Earlier we showed you the most obvious form of love songs, the Serenade. These songs describe a simple relationship: you love someone, and they love you back!
definingSerenades.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of songs that are Serenades vs all other songs, where each song is an individual bubble, with three playable Serenade category love songs annotated.

colorInHeartache.copy: But what happens if you love them, but they just... don‚Äôt? Maybe you broke up, or maybe it‚Äôs just unrequited. Let‚Äôs call this type of love song Heartache.
colorInHeartache.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of songs that are Serenades vs all other songs, where each song is an individual bubble, but Heartache songs have been highlighted within the non-Serenade songs. Three playable Heartache category love songs are annotated.

introducingHeartache.copy: Taylor Swift and Mariah Carey, ever the love-lorn crooners, top the Heartache category. (Explore all the artists with the search bar, where they‚Äôre sorted by how many of their songs fall in this category.)
introducingHeartache.figCaption: All eight hundred and thirty Heartache category love songs spread across a horizontal timeline from 1958 to 2023, appearing to remain fairly constant in popularity over time. Three playable songs are labeled.

heartacheComparedToSerenade.copy: The total number of Top 10 spots occupied by Heartache surpassed Serenades in the 2020s. Blinding Lights by The Weeknd played a big role, spending 57 weeks in the Top 10. Note: for each decade, love song types are sorted vertically by popularity (which is why Heartache jumps above Serenades in the 2020s).
heartacheComparedToSerenade.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of songs that are Serenades, Heartache and all other songs, where each song is an individual bubble. One playable Heartache category love song is annotated.

heartacheDoNotTipTheScales.copy: Did adding Heartache save the love song? Nope! Their decline is still dramatic: from 45% of all songs in the ‚Äô60s, to 27% in the 2020s.
heartacheDoNotTipTheScales.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of love songs (with Heartache included) vs all other songs, where the total popularity of all love songs decreases from SIXTIES_PERCENT% in the 60s to MODERN_PERCENT% in the 2020s, dropping most sharply after the 1990s.

introducingPursuit.copy: But we‚Äôre just getting started... How about when you love someone, and it might become something more? You just spotted someone, your heart is beating fast, and who KNOWS where this thing might lead? It might be time for a little Pursuit.
introducingPursuit.figCaption: All four hundred and forty Pursuit category love songs spread across a horizontal timeline from 1958 to 2023, appearing to remain fairly constant in popularity over time. Three playable songs are labeled.

pursuitHasNoEffect.copy: These Pursuit songs remain fairly steady over time, so the love song is still in decline and Boomer Boomer Bob remains right. I mean, what aspects of love could you sing about beyond new love, true love, and heartbreak?
pursuitHasNoEffect.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of love songs (with Pursuit included) vs all other songs, where the total popularity of all love songs decreases from SIXTIES_PERCENT% in the 60s to MODERN_PERCENT% in the 2020s, dropping most sharply after the 1990s.

introducingItsComplicated.copy: From our perspective: a lot, if you‚Äôre willing to explore the messier side of romance. What about when a relationship isn‚Äôt clearly good or bad? Maybe you fight constantly. Maybe they‚Äôre unfaithful. But you still try to make it work, because... well, It's Complicated!
introducingItsComplicated.figCaption: All four hundred and eighty It‚Äôs Complicated category love songs spread across a horizontal timeline from 1958 to 2023, steadily increasing in popularity over time. Three playable songs are labeled.

itsComplicatedDoesNotTipTheScales.copy: Can this angsty genre save the love song? No, but we‚Äôre getting closer!
itsComplicatedDoesNotTipTheScales.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of love songs (with It‚Äôs Complicated included) vs all other songs, where the total popularity of all love songs decreases from SIXTIES_PERCENT% in the 60s to MODERN_PERCENT% in the 2020s.

introducingGoodRiddance.copy: What about those songs where the relationship is clearly over, but the songwriter‚Äôs heartbreak has resurrected into... righteous power? They‚Äôre not crying, they‚Äôre yelling ‚ÄúGood Riddance!‚Äù
introducingGoodRiddance.figCaption: All one hundred and twenty five Good Riddance category love songs spread across a horizontal timeline from 1958 to 2023, largely increasing in popularity starting in the 2000s. Three playable songs are labeled.

goodRiddanceDoesNotTipTheScale.copy: With the predominantly modern Good Riddance love song added to the mix, maybe love is not dead -- it‚Äôs just a little wounded.
goodRiddanceDoesNotTipTheScale.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of love songs (with Good Riddance included) vs all other songs, where the total popularity of all love songs decreases from SIXTIES_PERCENT% in the 60s to MODERN_PERCENT% in the 2020s.

introducingSexualConfidence.copy: What about songs that get a little steamy? Think artists like Nicki Minaj and Drake, who dominate this category that's all about getting into bed with someone. Ah, the Sexual Confidence!
introducingSexualConfidence.figCaption: All three hundred and ten Sexual Confidence category love songs spread across a horizontal timeline from 1958 to 2023, generally increasing starting in the 1980s, with a spike in the 1990s. Three playable songs are labeled.

sexualConfidenceInContext.copy: As Boomers bemoan, these Sexual Confidence songs exploded in popularity, nearly eclipsing the Serenade in the 2000s. When we include this sensual side of love, the love song isn‚Äôt dying after all, but just as popular as in Boomer Bob‚Äôs day! But we‚Äôre not done quite yet.
sexualConfidenceInContext.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of love songs (with Sexual Confidence included) vs all other songs, where the total popularity of all love songs increases slightly from SIXTIES_PERCENT% in the 60s to MODERN_PERCENT% in the 2020s. Sexual Confidence is the second most popular love song category in the 1990s, but is otherwise one of the least popular categories.

introducingLoveSongForTheSelf.copy: We‚Äôve ventured very far from the Serenade. Far enough to find its reincarnation: songs where heartbreak turns love back onto the OG, yourself. ‚ÄúYou don't love me? That‚Äôs ok, because I do! In fact, I‚Äôll buy myself flowers‚Ä¶‚Äù
introducingLoveSongForTheSelf.figCaption: All one hundred and ten Love Song for the Self category love songs spread across a horizontal timeline from 1958 to 2023, generally sparse until the 2000s. Three playable songs are labeled.

didLoveSongForTheSelfTipTheScales.copy: This women-pioneered Love Song for the Self is the most modern of all the genres. And while it‚Äôs not written to a lover, it‚Äôs often written in reaction to romantic rejection. So now let‚Äôs return to our central question: Is the love song dying?
didLoveSongForTheSelfTipTheScales.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of love songs (with Love Song for the Self highlighted) vs all other songs, where Love Song for the Self is relatively obscure before increasing suddenly in the 2000s and finishing as the fifth most popular love song category in the 2020s, out of all seven categories.

theLoveSongIsActuallyRising.copy: Not at all. In fact, it‚Äôs increasingly more popular! The love song didn‚Äôt die; it evolved. People are loving, losing, and connecting in more ways than ever before. We argue that modern pop is just as love-struck as ever, just maybe in ways that Boomer Bob doesn‚Äôt recognize.
theLoveSongIsActuallyRising.figCaption: Chart of the proportion of love songs vs all other songs, where the total popularity of all love songs increases from SIXTIES_PERCENT% in the 60s to MODERN_PERCENT% in the 2020s. Individual love songs are now grouped into one aggregate category, emphasizing how the love songs have increased over time.

youDecide.copy:
That‚Äôs using our criteria. The status of love songs depends on what you believe should or should not count as a love song. So, you decide: remove categories
based on your love song beliefs, and tell us how the love song is doing!
youDecide.figCaption: SIXTIES_PERCENT% love songs in the 60s to MODERN_PERCENT% in the 2020s, visualized on a chart comparing the change of love song types over time, allowing you to add and remove each love song category and see how the proportion of all love songs changes over time based on that definition of what counts as a love song.
